Trigonometry

1. Sine rule

The sine rule: finding mistakes

In maths class you are learning about the sine rule. You are working on a problem in which the triangle has sides 44, 55, and 66, and two angles labelled AA and BB. You write down the sine rule equation for this triangle, as shown below. But your teacher walks by and tells you that there is a mistake in the equation.

Incorrect equation:

sinA4=sinB5
sinA4=sinB5

What should you do to correct the equation?

Answer:

To correct the equation you should .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Each fraction in the sine rule includes one side of the triangle and one angle. That side and angle must be opposite to each other in the triangle. The equation in this question includes the angles AA and BB. Are the sides in the equation both opposites of AA and BB?

STEP: Find the sides opposite to angles AA and BB
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The sine rule is an equation which connects two sides and two angles in any triangle:

asinA=bsinB or sinAa=sinBb
asinA or sinAa=bsinB=sinBb

where:

  • AA and BB are two angles in the triangle
  • aa is the side of the triangle opposite to angle AA
  • bb is the side of the triangle opposite to angle BB

For this question, that means these two sides are the important ones:

Note that 55 is not relevant because it is not opposite to either of the angles we know. And that is why the equation in this question is wrong:

sinA4=sinB5_
sinA4=sinB5⎯⎯

All four of these equations are correct for this triangle:

4sinA=6sinB or sinA4=sinB6 or 6sinB=4sinA or sinB6=sinA4
4sinA or sinA4 or 6sinB or sinB6=6sinB=sinB6=4sinA=sinA4
TIP: The equations above show that the sine rule is quite flexible. Keep this in mind when you are solving problems with the sine rule. You can simplify your work by choosing a more convenient arrangement.

To correct the equation, change the 55 to 66.

Submit your answer as:

Using the sine rule

Determine the unknown angle in the triangle shown. The triangle has two sides with lengths 11,711,7 and 8,48,4, and an angle shown which is 44°44°. The figure below is drawn to scale.

TIP: You can compare the answer you get to the diagram because it is drawn to scale. The angle that you want looks like it is something close to 90°90°, so check your answer before you submit it to make sure it agrees with the figure.
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the tenths place (one decimal) if necessary.
Answer: The missing angle is °
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

You should start by writing down the sine rule formula. Then you need to find pairs of angles and sides which are across from each other, and you can substitute them into the formula and go for it!

STEP: Choose which arrangement of the sine rule to use
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

The sine rule works for any triangle, and it relates two angles to the two sides opposite to those angles. We can use the sine rule in either of two ways:

Angles in numerators:sinˆAa=sinˆBbSides in numerators:asinˆA=bsinˆB
Angles in numerators:sinÂ aSides in numerators:asinÂ =sinB̂ b=bsinB̂ 

Both versions will work, but we should pick the version that makes it easier to solve the question. And in this case the first version above is the better choice because we want to find an angle and it is easier to solve equations when the unknown variable is in the numerator of a fraction (instead of the denominator). So it will be easier to use this arrangement of the formula:

sinˆAa=sinˆBb
sinÂ a=sinB̂ b
STEP: Substitute in the known values
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

When using the sine rule, we must substitute in the values carefully to make sure that they are in the correct places. Each fraction must have an angle and the side of the triangle opposite from each other. It can be helpful to circle and connect these opposite pairs, like this:

Notice that we also labelled the vertices of the triangle, in case that will be helpful. In fact, the angle we want is ˆCĈ . We can use that in our equation:

sinˆC11,7=sin(44°)8,4
sinĈ 11,7=sin(44°)8,4
STEP: Solve for the missing angle
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

Now it is a matter of solving for ˆCĈ .

sinˆC11,7=sin(44°)8,4sinˆC11,7=(0,69465...)8,4sinˆC=(0,08269...)(11,7)sinˆC=0,96755...
sinĈ 11,7sinĈ 11,7sinĈ sinĈ =sin(44°)8,4=(0,69465...)8,4=(0,08269...)(11,7)=0,96755...
At this point we must use the inverse sine operation. Whenever we do that, we must remember the second group of solutions and the +360°k+360°k business. The good news is that we can ignore the +360°k+360°k term now: we know the angle must be between zero and 180°180° because it is in a triangle. However, we cannot ignore the second solution: we must figure out if it gives us a real answer or not. (Remember that the second solution for the sine function comes from 180∘−θ180∘−θ, where θθ is whatever angle you get from your calculator.)
ˆC=sin−1(0,96755...)ˆC=75,36610...°or104,63389...°
Ĉ Ĉ =sin−1(0,96755...)=75,36610...°or104,63389...°

Now we must figure out which of these answers is correct. Or are they both possible? It turns out that the first answer, ˆC≈75,4°Ĉ ≈75,4°, is the only possible answer. We know this by comparing to the diagram: the angle we want is an acute angle (less than 90°90°). So while 104,6°104,6° is a valid solution to the equation we solved, it is not a valid angle for the triangle in this question.

NOTE: It is possible that a question like this will have two solutions, or that the obtuse angle is the correct answer. For example, if the diagram was not drawn to scale, we could not assume that the angle is acute. You should not assume that the answer will always be an acute angle!

The instructions said to round to one decimal place, so the final answer is ˆC=75,4°Ĉ =75,4°.

Working algebraically: finding a sine ratio

Triangle BACBAC is shown below with sides labelled 5x+45x+4, 5x5x, and 20x520x5. All three of these expression are non-zero. ∠A∠A is labelled αα. The diagram is not drawn to scale.

  1. Determine an expression for sinαsinα in terms of xx and sinBsinB.

    Answer: sinα=sinα=
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The answer should be "in terms of xx and sinBsinB". That means the answer will include both the variable xx and the expression sinBsinB. You can get both of these into an equation using the sine rule.

    STEP: Set up an equation using sinBsinB and xx
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    The question says that we need an answer "in terms of xx and sinBsinB". That means we want an expression which includes both xx and the expression sinBsinB. How can we do that? We can use the sine rule!

    sinα20x5=sinB5x
    sinα20x5=sinB5x
    STEP: Solve for sinαsinα
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

    We want an expression for sinαsinα. So we need to rearrange the equation above to make sinαsinα the subject. To do this, multiply both sides of the equation by 20x520x5.

    sinα20x5=sinB5xsinα=sinB5x⋅(20x5)
    sinα20x5sinα=sinB5x=sinB5x⋅(20x5)
    STEP: Simplify the expression as much as possible
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    The result above agrees with the question: it is an expression for sinαsinα in terms of both xx and sinBsinB. But we can simplify the expression on the right side: we can factorise the numerator. In fact, we can split the numerator such that we get a factor which matches the denominator.

    sinα=sinB5x⋅(20x5)=(20x5)⋅sinB5x=(4x4)(5x)⋅sinB5x=(4x4)sinB
    sinα=sinB5x⋅(20x5)=(20x5)⋅sinB5x=(4x4)(5x)⋅sinB5x=(4x4)sinB

    And there we have it: the expression for sinαsinα in terms of xx and sinBsinB is (4x4)sinB(4x4)sinB.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Question 1 states that the three side expressions are non-zero. Why must those expressions be non-zero?

    Answer:

    The expressions must be non-zero .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Any time there are fractions involved in a calculation, you must worry about division by zero. Why is that?

    STEP: Select the correct answer
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to identify the reason why the side expressions for the triangle must be non-zero. The reason is a common one: whenever there are fractions, we must be sure not to divide by zero. The solution to Question 1 uses the sine rule, and that includes fractions. So the statement "All three of these expression are non-zero" prevents division by zero. And that prevents undefined fractions.

    The correct answer is that the expression must be non-zero to avoid undefined fractions.

Finding an angle with the sine rule

In ΔYWXΔYWX, ˆX=95°X̂ =95°, XY=4,6 cmXY=4,6 cm, and YW=6,7 cmYW=6,7 cm.

Calculate the size of ˆWŴ .

INSTRUCTION: Round the answer to two decimal places.
Answer: ˆW=Ŵ = °°
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by writing an equation using the sine rule. The equation should look like this:

sinˆWa side=sin(an angle)another side
sinŴ a side=sin(an angle)another side
STEP: Write an equation using the sine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We have a triangle with two sides and one angle labelled. And we are looking for an angle. This is a sine rule situation, because the sine rule always includes two sides and two angles in a triangle.

TIP:

There are two ways we can write the sine rule. Choose the way that makes it the easiest to solve the question:

  • Angles in numerators and sides in denominators: sinˆAa=sinˆBbsinÂ a=sinB̂ b
  • Sides in numerators and angles in denominators: asinˆA=bsinˆBasinÂ =bsinB̂ 

Write the equation so that whatever you need to solve for is in the numerator.

Using the given information, we can write:

sinˆAa=sinˆBbsinˆW(4,6)=sin(95°)(6,7)
sinÂ asinŴ (4,6)=sinB̂ b=sin(95°)(6,7)
STEP: Solve for sinˆWsinŴ 
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

The first step in solving for the angle is to multiply both sides of the equation by 4,64,6. This will isolate sinˆWsinŴ . Then evaluate the expression on the right side.

sinˆW(4,6)=sin(95°)(6,7)sinˆW=sin(95°)(6,7)⋅4,6sinˆW=0,68395...
sinŴ (4,6)sinŴ sinŴ =sin(95°)(6,7)=sin(95°)(6,7)⋅4,6=0,68395...
STEP: Use the inverse sine function to find the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to use the inverse sine function to isolate the angle. (Inverses undo each other, so the inverse sine function will take the sine function away from angle ˆWŴ .) As always, we do this on both sides of the equation. Then use a calculator to evaluate the result.

sinˆW=0,68395...sin−1(sinˆW)=sin−1(0,68395...)ˆW=43,15344...ˆW≈43,15°
sinŴ sin−1(sinŴ )Ŵ Ŵ =0,68395...=sin−1(0,68395...)=43,15344...≈43,15°

From our calculators we get one answer. However, the inverse sine function provides two more things that the calculator does not show us! Firstly, we get a second answer, which is 180°−43,15°180°−43,15°. Secondly, the sine curve repeats every 360°360°. That means we actually get these solutions to the equation:

ˆW=43,15°+360°k,k∈ZˆW=136,85°+360°k,k∈Z
Ŵ Ŵ =43,15°+360°k,k∈ℤ=136,85°+360°k,k∈ℤ

These are all the answers to the equation (there are an infinite number of them). But this question is about an angle in a triangle. This answer represents something real so the answer needs to be realistic. That means that we can ignore the +360°k+360°k terms because the answer must be between 0°0° and 180°180° (angles cannot be negative and angles in a triangle have a sum of 180°180°). Additionally, there is already an angle of 95°95° in the triangle, so angle ˆWŴ  must be less than 90°90° (because the sum of all three angles is 180°180°). Therefore, the only answer which is acceptable is ˆW=43,15°Ŵ =43,15°.

The size of ˆWŴ  is 43,15°43,15°.

The flexibility of the sine rule

The diagram below shows a triangle, drawn to scale. Two angles are shown, with values of 35°35° and 56°56°. The side of the triangle across from the 56∘56∘ angle has a length of 9,59,5 units.

  1. Suppose you need to calculate xx, the side across from the 35∘35∘ angle. The two equations below are both accurate and you can use either of these versions to find xx. But one choice makes the solution a bit easier. Which version is the better choice?

    Version 1 xsin(35°)=9,5sin(56°)xsin(35°)=9,5sin(56°)
    Version 2 sin(35°)x=sin(56°)9,5sin(35°)x=sin(56°)9,5
    Answer: The better choice is: .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about solving equations these two equations for yy:

    y5=710or5y=107
    y5=710or5y=107

    The equation on the left is more convenient to solve. Why?

    STEP: Choose the version with the needed value in the numerator
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We can arrange the sine rule in two different ways. We can either put the angles in the numerator with the sides in the denominator, or the other way around:

    Angles in numerators andsides in denominators:sinˆAa=sinˆBbSides in numerators andangles in denominators:asinˆA=bsinˆB
    Angles in numerators andsides in denominators:sinÂ aSides in numerators andangles in denominators:asinÂ =sinB̂ b=bsinB̂ 

    In both equations, aa and bb represent sides of the triangle and ˆAÂ  and ˆBB̂  represent angles. Solving equations with the unknown value in the numerator is usually easier than solving equations with the unknown in the denominator. So we should use the arrangement which will put the value we want to find in the numerator.

    In this question, we have two versions of the sine rule for the triangle given. Both of these versions are correct. But since we want to find a side the choice with the sides in the numerators is the better choice.

    The correct choice is Version 1.

  2. Now solve for the missing side, xx. Use the equation identified in Question 1.

    INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the tenths place (one decimal) if necessary.

    xsin(35°)=9,5sin(56°)

    You need to solve for xx.

    STEP: Solve for the missing side
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    xsin(35°)=9,5sin(56°)xsin(35°)=9,5(0,82903...)xsin(35°)=11,45907...

    x=(11,45907...)⋅sin(35°)x=6,57265...x≈6,6
    xxx=(11,45907...)⋅sin(35°)=6,57265...≈6,6

    And that's the answer. The final step rounds the answer to one decimal place, as required in the instructions.

    The unknown side of the triangle has a length of 6,66,6.

The sine rule: identifying the correct sides and angles

The triangle below has sides labelled a,ba,b, and mm, and angles labelled α,βα,β, and θθ.

For this triangle, the sine rule states:

sinθm=sin?b
sinθm=sin?b

Which of the following choices belongs in the place of the '?' in the formula?

Answer: The missing symbol is: .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Each fraction in the sine rule has an angle and a side. The side must be the side opposite from the angle. Look in the picture of the triangle for sides and angles which are across from (opposite) each other in the triangle.

STEP: Connect the sides and angles in the diagram according to the sine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

In the sine rule, each fraction must contain a side and an angle. These values (the side and the angle) must be opposite (across from) each other in the triangle. For example, in the triangle in this question, the angle θθ and side mm are opposite each other.

We are given the formula:

sinθm=sin?b
sinθm=sin?b

The question mark is in the position of one of the angles. Since the fraction with the question mark has the side bb in it, the angle we need must be opposite from side bb.

The missing variable in the equation is the angle β.

Find the missing length

In triangle ACBACB, two angles are known: ˆA=62°Â =62° and ˆC=60°Ĉ =60°. Sides ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ and ¯BABA⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ have lengths 5d+45d+4 and 25d2−1625d2−16 respectively, where d∈Rd∈ℝ. All lengths are non-zero and have units of mmmm.

Compute then length of ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The length of ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ is mmmm.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by drawing a diagram of the triangle. Label it with everything you know. Then use the sine rule to write an equation which includes the variable dd.

STEP: Draw a picture of the triangle and label it
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

The first thing to do is draw a picture. The question tells us a lot about a triangle, but we need to organise that information in a diagram. It is important to label everything you know about the triangle.

NOTE: The diagram does not need to be to scale. But the labels should be accurate. And since the diagram is not to scale, we cannot draw any conclusions from the picture itself.
STEP: Write an equation including dd
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

We need to determine the value of dd. We can do this using the sine rule. We can arrange the sine rule in various ways. In this case, the expression 25d2−1625d2−16 can be factorised, and it has a common factor with 5d+45d+4! So it looks like we will be able to cancel something. Let's put the side equal to 25d2−1625d2−16 in the left numerator so that we can get a more convenient equation to solve.

25d2−16sin60°=5d+4sin62°
25d2−16sin60°=5d+4sin62°
STEP: Solve for dd
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

We need to get the dd terms on one side of the equation. After that, we can factorise and simplify on the left side.

25d2−16sin60°=5d+4sin62°25d2−165d+4=sin60°sin62°(5d−4)(5d+4)5d+4=sin60°sin62°5d−4=sin60°sin62°
25d2−16sin60°25d2−165d+4(5d−4)(5d+4)5d+45d−4=5d+4sin62°=sin60°sin62°=sin60°sin62°=sin60°sin62°

Now isolate the dd on the left side. You can evaluate the sine functions on the right now if you want, but leaving them will be helpful because we can avoid dragging long decimal numbers around.

5d−4=sin60°sin62°d=(sin60°sin62°+4)⋅15d=0,99616...
5d−4dd=sin60°sin62°=(sin60°sin62°+4)⋅15=0,99616...

Do not round this number yet - we need to use it in the final calculation.

STEP: Compute the length of ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

Finally we can evaluate the length of ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯.

¯CB=5d+4=5(0,99616...)+4=8,98083...≈8,98 mm
CB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=5d+4=5(0,99616...)+4=8,98083...≈8,98 mm

As long as this number is positive, it is acceptable (lengths cannot be negative). So we are done.

The length of ¯CBCB⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ is 8,98 mm8,98 mm.

Connecting the sine rule to right triangles

  1. The sine rule applies to any triangle. This includes right-angled triangles. Which statement below identifies what happens to the sine rule if one of the angles is 90°90°?

    Choices If an angle is 90°90°, the sine rule...
    A becomes the sine ratio (opposite & hypotenuse).
    B will not work anymore.
    C only uses the reciprocals.
    D becomes the same as the theorom of Pythagoras.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a triangle to represent the situation described in the question. Then work out the sine rule including the right angle.

    STEP: Find the link between the sine rule and right-angled triangles
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about what happens when we use a 90°90° angle in the sine rule. If one of the angles is 90°90° then we have a right-angled triangle. For example:

    Since this is a right-angled triangle, the normal trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, and tangent) apply to the triangle. But so does the sine rule. And if we include the right angle when we write the sine rule, it simplifies into the sine ratio for right-angled triangles. (Question 2 is about why this happens.)

    The correct choice is A.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. The table below shows (proves) that if we use the sine rule with a 90°90° angle it simplifies into the sine ratio for right-angled triangles. However, there is one missing step and one missing reason. Complete the proof by choosing the correct options from the lists available.

    Answer:
    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    Sine rule for ΔXYZΔXYZ
    sinXx=sin(90°)zsinXx=sin(90°)z Substitute Z=90°Z=90°

    sinX=xzsinX=xz Multiply by xx

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Start by analysing the steps and reasons which are already shown. Think about what they mean. Then try to decide what the missing pieces should be.

    STEP: Select the correct step and reason
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The proof in this question connects the sine rule to right-angled triangles. In such a case, the sine rule becomes the sine ratio for a right-angled triangle. In other words, the sine rule ends up being equivalent to the ratio "opposite over hypotenuse." This connection between the sine rule and the sine ratio exists because sin90°sin90° is equal to 11.

    The correct answers in the proof are shown below.

    Steps Reasons

The flexibility of the sine rule

The sine rule describes the relationship between the sides and angles in any triangle. The ratio of any side to the sine of the angle opposite from that side is the same for all three side-angle pairs in the triangle. For example, consider this triangle, which has sides nn, pp, and mm, and angles GG, HH, and FF. Two of the three equal ratios are shown below the triangle.

sinHm=sinFn=third ratio
sinHm=sinFn=third ratio

Which of the choices below is the third equal ratio for this triangle?

A sinFpsinFp
B sinGpsinGp
C sinHpsinHp
Answer: The third ratio is choice .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Start by figuring out which side and which angle are not used in the two ratios given in the question. They must be in the answer.

STEP: Compare the given ratios to the triangle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about how we can apply the sine rule to a triangle. Each ratio (fraction) in the sine rule contains one side and one angle in the triangle. For any triangle there are three equal ratios. In this question we have two of those ratios for the triangle shown above. We need to find the third equal ratio.

The sine rule always includes side-angle pairs which are across from each other in the triangle. There are always three of these pairs, as shown below:

Each of the linked pairs above corresponds to a ratio for the sine rule. In fact, the two ratios given in the question each include one of the linked pairs:

sinHm=sinFn↑↑side m isside n isacross fromacross fromangle Hangle F
sinHm↑side m isacross fromangle H=sinFn↑side n isacross fromangle F

The third side-angle pair is side pp and angle GG. These values must be in the third ratio!

sinHm=sinFn=sinGp
sinHm=sinFn=sinGp
NOTE:

We can also write the ratios upside down, but if we do this then all the ratios should match:

msinH=nsinF=psinG
msinH=nsinF=psinG

The correct answer is sinGpsinGp, which is choice B.

Sine rule problems

In the figure below, RˆSP=fRŜ P=f, SˆPR=gSP̂ R=g, and RP=hRP=h. PSPS and RQRQ are perpendicular to QPQP.

Determine the distance PSPS in terms of ff, gg, and hh.

Answer: PS=PS=
expression
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by writing an equation about triangle SRPSRP. You need this equation to include ff, gg, and hh. So focus on the sides and angles which will bring those variables into the equation.

STEP: Add any information you can to the diagram
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We need to find an equation for PSPS in terms of the three variables ff, gg, and hh. So we need to write an equation about the diagram which includes all four of those things.

How to do that is not obvious because the diagram is a bit complex. Which triangle should we use? Can we take advantage of the right-angles? It is not easy to know at the beginning. So as a first step, we can examine the diagram and label any extra information we can find in the figure.

In this case, we can know four new pieces of information:

  • PSPS and RQRQ must be parallel to each other because they are both perpendicular to QPQP.
  • QˆPR=90°−gQP̂ R=90°−g because it is complementary to angle gg.
  • QˆRP=gQR̂ P=g because it is an alternate interior angle with gg (PSPS and RQRQ are parallel).
  • SˆRPSR̂ P must be 180°−(f+g)180°−(f+g) because the angles in ΔSRPΔSRP add up to 180°180°.

At this point we do not know if any of that information will be useful. We will find out!

STEP: Write an equation and try to include ff, gg, and hh
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

Now let's write an equation about the diagram. We need an equation which includes the variables ff, gg, and hh (because those must be in the answer). So we need to focus on the sides and angles which will bring those variables into the equation. The equation must also include side PSPS.

We can try the sine rule. We can get everything we need into the equation if we focus on the sides and angles in ΔSRPΔSRP.

PSsin(180°−(f+g))=hsinf
PSsin(180°−(f+g))=hsinf

Now we are in business: the answer must be in terms of ff, gg. And those are the variables in the equation (in addition to PSPS).

STEP: Simplify the equation to get the expected form
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We need to solve the equation for PSPS. To do this, multiply both sides of the equation by sin(180°−(f+g))sin(180°−(f+g)).

PS=h⋅sin(180°−(f+g))sinf
PS=h⋅sin(180°−(f+g))sinf

Now we can use a trigonometric identity to simplify this equation. We know that sin(180°−A)sin(180°−A) is equal to sinAsinA. So the quantity sin(180°−(f+g))sin(180°−(f+g)) is equal to sin(f+g)sin(f+g)!

PS=h⋅sin(180°−(f+g))sinfPS=h⋅sin(f+g)sinf
PSPS=h⋅sin(180°−(f+g))sinf=h⋅sin(f+g)sinf

That gives us a tidy and accurate expression for PSPS in terms of the required values.

The length of PSPS, as a function of ff, gg, and hh is h⋅sin(f+g)sinfh⋅sin(f+g)sinf.

The sine rule: finding mistakes

In maths class you are learning about the sine rule. You are working on a problem in which the triangle has sides 44, 66, and 77, and two angles labelled AA and BB. You write down the sine rule equation for this triangle, as shown below. But your teacher walks by and tells you that there is a mistake in the equation.

Incorrect equation:

7sinA=4sinB
7sinA=4sinB

What should you do to correct the equation?

Answer:

To correct the equation you should .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Each fraction in the sine rule includes one side of the triangle and one angle. That side and angle must be opposite to each other in the triangle. The equation in this question includes the angles AA and BB. Are the sides in the equation both opposites of AA and BB?

STEP: Find the sides opposite to angles AA and BB
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The sine rule is an equation which connects two sides and two angles in any triangle:

asinA=bsinB or sinAa=sinBb
asinA or sinAa=bsinB=sinBb

where:

  • AA and BB are two angles in the triangle
  • aa is the side of the triangle opposite to angle AA
  • bb is the side of the triangle opposite to angle BB

For this question, that means these two sides are the important ones:

Note that 77 is not relevant because it is not opposite to either of the angles we know. And that is why the equation in this question is wrong:

7_sinA=4sinB
7⎯⎯sinA=4sinB

All four of these equations are correct for this triangle:

6sinA=4sinB or sinA6=sinB4 or 4sinB=6sinA or sinB4=sinA6
6sinA or sinA6 or 4sinB or sinB4=4sinB=sinB4=6sinA=sinA6
TIP: The equations above show that the sine rule is quite flexible. Keep this in mind when you are solving problems with the sine rule. You can simplify your work by choosing a more convenient arrangement.

To correct the equation, change the 77 to 66.

However, we cannot ignore the second solution: we must figure out if it gives us a real answer or not. (Remember that the second solution for the sine function comes from 180∘−θ, where θ is whatever angle you get from your calculator.)
ˆC=sin−1(0,92103...)ˆC=67,07782...°or112,92217...°

Now we must figure out which of these answers is correct. Or are they both possible? It turns out that the first answer, ˆC≈67,1°, is the only possible answer. We know this by comparing to the diagram: the angle we want is an acute angle (less than 90°). So while 112,9° is a valid solution to the equation we solved, it is not a valid angle for the triangle in this question.

NOTE: It is possible that a question like this will have two solutions, or that the obtuse angle is the correct answer. For example, if the diagram was not drawn to scale, we could not assume that the angle is acute. You should not assume that the answer will always be an acute angle!

The instructions said to round to one decimal place, so the final answer is ˆC=67,1°.

Working algebraically: finding a sine ratio

Triangle CAB is shown below with sides labelled 16x2−9, x3, and 4x−3. All three of these expression are non-zero. ∠A is labelled θ. The diagram is not drawn to scale.

  1. Determine an expression for sinθ in terms of x and sinB.

    Answer: sinθ=
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The answer should be "in terms of x and sinB". That means the answer will include both the variable x and the expression sinB. You can get both of these into an equation using the sine rule.

    STEP: Set up an equation using sinB and x
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    The question says that we need an answer "in terms of x and sinB". That means we want an expression which includes both x and the expression sinB. How can we do that? We can use the sine rule!

    sinθ16x2−9=sinB4x−3
    STEP: Solve for sinθ
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

    We want an expression for sinθ. So we need to rearrange the equation above to make sinθ the subject. To do this, multiply both sides of the equation by 16x2−9.

    sinθ16x2−9=sinB4x−3sinθ=sinB4x−3⋅(16x2−9)
    STEP: Simplify the expression as much as possible
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    The result above agrees with the question: it is an expression for sinθ in terms of both x and sinB. But we can simplify the expression on the right side: we can factorise the numerator. It is a difference of two squares.

    sinθ=sinB4x−3⋅(16x2−9)=(16x2−9)⋅sinB4x−3=(4x+3)(4x−3)⋅sinB4x−3=(4x+3)sinB

    And there we have it: the expression for sinθ in terms of x and sinB is (4x+3)sinB.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Question 1 states that the three side expressions are non-zero. Why must those expressions be non-zero?

    Answer:

    The expressions must be non-zero .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Any time there are fractions involved in a calculation, you must worry about division by zero. Why is that?

    STEP: Select the correct answer
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to identify the reason why the side expressions for the triangle must be non-zero. The reason is a common one: whenever there are fractions, we must be sure not to divide by zero. The solution to Question 1 uses the sine rule, and that includes fractions. So the statement "All three of these expression are non-zero" prevents division by zero. And that prevents undefined fractions.

    The correct answer is that the expression must be non-zero to avoid undefined fractions.

    STEP: Solve for sinα

Finding an angle with the sine rule

In ΔQRP, ˆP=101°, PQ=3 cm, and QR=7 cm.

Calculate the size of ˆR.

INSTRUCTION: Round the answer to two decimal places.
Answer: ˆR= °
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by writing an equation using the sine rule. The equation should look like this:

sinˆRa side=sin(an angle)another side
STEP: Write an equation using the sine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We have a triangle with two sides and one angle labelled. And we are looking for an angle. This is a sine rule situation, because the sine rule always includes two sides and two angles in a triangle.

TIP:

There are two ways we can write the sine rule. Choose the way that makes it the easiest to solve the question:

  • Angles in numerators and sides in denominators: sinˆAa=sinˆBb
  • Sides in numerators and angles in denominators: asinˆA=bsinˆB

Write the equation so that whatever you need to solve for is in the numerator.

Using the given information, we can write:

sinˆAa=sinˆBbsinˆR(3)=sin(101°)(7)
STEP: Solve for sinˆR
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

The first step in solving for the angle is to multiply both sides of the equation by 3. This will isolate sinˆR. Then evaluate the expression on the right side.

sinˆR(3)=sin(101°)(7)sinˆR=sin(101°)(7)⋅3sinˆR=0,42069...
STEP: Use the inverse sine function to find the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to use the inverse sine function to isolate the angle. (Inverses undo each other, so the inverse sine function will take the sine function away from angle ˆR.) As always, we do this on both sides of the equation. Then use a calculator to evaluate the result.

sinˆR=0,42069...sin−1(sinˆR)=sin−1(0,42069...)ˆR=24,87862...ˆR≈24,88°

From our calculators we get one answer. However, the inverse sine function provides two more things that the calculator does not show us! Firstly, we get a second answer, which is 180°−24,88°. Secondly, the sine curve repeats every 360°. That means we actually get these solutions to the equation:

ˆR=24,88°+360°k,k∈ZˆR=155,12°+360°k,k∈Z

These are all the answers to the equation (there are an infinite number of them). But this question is about an angle in a triangle. This answer represents something real so the answer needs to be realistic. That means that we can ignore the +360°k terms because the answer must be between 0° and 180° (angles cannot be negative and angles in a triangle have a sum of 180°). Additionally, there is already an angle of 101° in the triangle, so angle ˆR must be less than 90° (because the sum of all three angles is 180°). Therefore, the only answer which is acceptable is ˆR=24,88°.

The size of ˆR is 24,88°.

Submit your answer as:

The flexibility of the sine rule

The diagram below shows a triangle, drawn to scale. One of the sides has a length of 7,8 and another side has the length 7. The angle across from the side labelled 7 is 50°.

  1. Suppose you need to calculate x, the angle across from the side with length 7,8. The two equations below are both accurate and you can use either of these versions to find x. But one choice makes the solution a bit easier. Which version is the better choice?

    Version 1 sinx7,8=sin(50°)7
    Version 2 7,8sinx=7sin(50°)
    Answer: The better choice is: .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about solving equations these two equations for y:

    y5=710or5y=107

    The equation on the left is more convenient to solve. Why?

    STEP: Choose the version with the needed value in the numerator
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We can arrange the sine rule in two different ways. We can either put the angles in the numerator with the sides in the denominator, or the other way around:

    Angles in numerators andsides in denominators:sinˆAa=sinˆBbSides in numerators andangles in denominators:asinˆA=bsinˆB

    In both equations, a and b represent sides of the triangle and ˆA and ˆB represent angles. Solving equations with the unknown value in the numerator is usually easier than solving equations with the unknown in the denominator. So we should use the arrangement which will put the value we want to find in the numerator.

    In this question, we have two versions of the sine rule for the triangle given. Both of these versions are correct. But since we want to find an angle the choice with the angles in the numerators is the better choice.

    The correct choice is Version 1.

    INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the tenths place (one decimal) if necessary.

    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    [−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    sinx7,8=sin(50°)7sinx7,8=(0,76604...)7sinx7,8=0,10943...sinx=(0,10943...)(7,8)sinx=0,85359...

    x=sin−1(0,85359...)x=58,60457...°or121,39542...°

?sinA=csinC

Find the missing length

In triangle DFE, two angles are known: ˆD=43° and ˆF=40°. Sides ¯FE and ¯ED have lengths 3h+2 and 6h2+4h respectively, where h∈R. All lengths are non-zero and have units of mm.

Find then length of ¯ED.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The length of ¯ED is mm.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by drawing a diagram of the triangle. Label it with everything you know. Then use the sine rule to write an equation which includes the variable h.

STEP: Draw a picture of the triangle and label it
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

The first thing to do is draw a picture. The question tells us a lot about a triangle, but we need to organise that information in a diagram. It is important to label everything you know about the triangle.

NOTE: The diagram does not need to be to scale. But the labels should be accurate. And since the diagram is not to scale, we cannot draw any conclusions from the picture itself.
STEP: Write an equation including h
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

We need to determine the value of h. We can do this using the sine rule. We can arrange the sine rule in various ways. In this case, the expression 6h2+4h can be factorised, and it has a common factor with 3h+2! So it looks like we will be able to cancel something. Let's put the side equal to 6h2+4h in the left numerator so that we can get a more convenient equation to solve.

6h2+4hsin40°=3h+2sin43°
STEP: Solve for h
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

We need to get the h terms on one side of the equation. After that, we can factorise and simplify on the left side.

6h2+4hsin40°=3h+2sin43°6h2+4h3h+2=sin40°sin43°(2h)(3h+2)3h+2=sin40°sin43°2h=sin40°sin43°

Now isolate the h on the left side. You can evaluate the sine functions on the right now if you want, but leaving them will be helpful because we can avoid dragging long decimal numbers around.

2h=sin40°sin43°h=(sin40°sin43°)⋅12h=0,47125...

Do not round this number yet - we need to use it in the final calculation.

STEP: Compute the length of ¯ED
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

Finally we can evaluate the length of ¯ED.

¯ED=6h2+4h=6(0,47125...)2+4(0,47125...)=3,21748...≈3,22 mm

As long as this number is positive, it is acceptable (lengths cannot be negative). So we are done.

The length of ¯ED is 3,22 mm.

Connecting the sine rule to right triangles

  1. The sine rule applies to any triangle. This includes right-angled triangles. Which statement below identifies what happens to the sine rule if one of the angles is 90°?

    Choices If an angle is 90°, the sine rule...
    A only works for the acute angles.
    B only uses the reciprocals.
    C becomes the same as the theorom of Pythagoras.
    D becomes the sine ratio (opposite & hypotenuse).
    Answer:

    The correct statement is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a triangle to represent the situation described in the question. Then work out the sine rule including the right angle.

    STEP: Find the link between the sine rule and right-angled triangles
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about what happens when we use a 90° angle in the sine rule. If one of the angles is 90° then we have a right-angled triangle. For example:

    Since this is a right-angled triangle, the normal trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, and tangent) apply to the triangle. But so does the sine rule. And if we include the right angle when we write the sine rule, it simplifies into the sine ratio for right-angled triangles. (Question 2 is about why this happens.)

    The correct choice is D.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. The table below shows (proves) that if we use the sine rule with a 90° angle it simplifies into the sine ratio for right-angled triangles. However, there is one missing step and one missing reason. Complete the proof by choosing the correct options from the lists available.

    Answer:
    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    sinXx=sinZz Sine rule for ΔXYZ
    Substitute Z=90°
    sinXx=1z Evaluate sin90°=1
    sinX=xz
    sinX=oppositehypotenuse Definition of opposite & hypotenuse
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Start by analysing the steps and reasons which are already shown. Think about what they mean. Then try to decide what the missing pieces should be.

    STEP: Select the correct step and reason
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The proof in this question connects the sine rule to right-angled triangles. In such a case, the sine rule becomes the sine ratio for a right-angled triangle. In other words, the sine rule ends up being equivalent to the ratio "opposite over hypotenuse." This connection between the sine rule and the sine ratio exists because sin90° is equal to 1.

    The correct answers in the proof are shown below.

    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    sinXx=sinZz Sine rule for ΔXYZ
    sinXx=sin(90°)z Substitute Z=90°
    sinXx=1z Evaluate sin90°=1
    sinX=xz Multiply by x
    sinX=oppositehypotenuse Definition of opposite & hypotenuse
    Submit your answer as: and

The flexibility of the sine rule

The sine rule describes the relationship between the sides and angles in any triangle. The ratio of any side to the sine of the angle opposite from that side is the same for all three side-angle pairs in the triangle. For example, consider this triangle, which has sides p, n, and m, and angles S, Q, and R. Two of the three equal ratios are shown below the triangle.

sinQm=sinRp=third ratio

Which of the choices below is the third equal ratio for this triangle?

A sinSp
B sinSn
C sinRn
Answer: The third ratio is choice .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Start by figuring out which side and which angle are not used in the two ratios given in the question. They must be in the answer.

STEP: Compare the given ratios to the triangle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about how we can apply the sine rule to a triangle. Each ratio (fraction) in the sine rule contains one side and one angle in the triangle. For any triangle there are three equal ratios. In this question we have two of those ratios for the triangle shown above. We need to find the third equal ratio.

The sine rule always includes side-angle pairs which are across from each other in the triangle. There are always three of these pairs, as shown below:

Each of the linked pairs above corresponds to a ratio for the sine rule. In fact, the two ratios given in the question each include one of the linked pairs:

sinQm=sinRp↑↑side m isside p isacross fromacross fromangle Qangle R

The third side-angle pair is side n and angle S. These values must be in the third ratio!

sinQm=sinRp=sinSn
NOTE:

We can also write the ratios upside down, but if we do this then all the ratios should match:

msinQ=psinR=nsinS

The correct answer is sinSn, which is choice B.

Submit your answer as:

Finding a length with the sine rule

The diagram below shows a triangle with two angles and one side labelled. The given angles are 59° and 35°. The side across from the 35° angle is 4. Determine the length of the side across from the 59° angle. The figure is drawn to scale.

TIP: This diagram is drawn to scale so you can compare the answer you get to the diagram. The side you need is longer than the given side 4. Check your answer before you submit it to make sure it agrees with the figure.
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places if necessary.
Answer: The length of the side is .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

You should start by writing down the sine rule formula. Then you need to find pairs of angles and sides which are across from each other, and you can substitute them into the formula. Then solve for the missing side.

STEP: Choose which arrangement of the sine rule to use
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

The sine rule works for any triangle. It relates four pieces of information in the triangle: two angles and two sides. These angles and sides must be pairs of opposites. We can use the sine rule in either of these ways:

Angles in numerators andsides in denominators:sinˆAa=sinˆBbSides in numerators andangles in denominators:asinˆA=bsinˆB

We should pick the version that makes it easier to solve the question. To find a length, the second version above is the better choice. This is because it is easier to solve equations when the unknown variable is in the numerator of a fraction (instead of the denominator). So we will use this arrangement of the formula:

asinˆA=bsinˆB
STEP: Substitute in the known values
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

When using the sine rule, we must make sure we substitute the values into the correct places. Each fraction must have an angle and the side of the triangle opposite from each other. It can be helpful to circle and connect these opposite pairs, like this:

Each of the arrows above connects numbers that belong together in one fraction. Let's use x to represent the side we are looking for (the one with the '?').

xsin(59°)=4sin(35°)
STEP: Solve for the missing side
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now we can solve for x. First we can evaluate everything on the right side.

xsin(59°)=4sin(35°)xsin(59°)=4(0,57357...)xsin(59°)=6,97378...

Next, we multiply both sides of the equation by sin(59°) to cancel the denominator on the left.

x=(6,97378...)⋅sin(59°)x=5,97770...x≈5,98

The final step rounds the answer to two decimal places, as required in the instructions. Based on the diagram, we expected the answer to be longer than than 4. And it is! Remember to compare your answer to the diagram if the diagram is to scale.

The length of the missing side is 5,98.

STEP: Choose which arrangement of the sine rule to use

The sine rule works for any triangle. It relates four pieces of information in the triangle: two angles and two sides. These angles and sides must be pairs of opposites. We can use the sine rule in either of these ways:

Angles in numerators andsides in denominators:sinˆAa=sinˆBbSides in numerators andangles in denominators:asinˆA=bsinˆB

We should pick the version that makes it easier to solve the question. To find a length, the second version above is the better choice. This is because it is easier to solve equations when the unknown variable is in the numerator of a fraction (instead of the denominator). So we will use this arrangement of the formula:

asinˆA=bsinˆB
STEP: Substitute in the known values
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

When using the sine rule, we must make sure we substitute the values into the correct places. Each fraction must have an angle and the side of the triangle opposite from each other. It can be helpful to circle and connect these opposite pairs, like this:

Each of the arrows above connects numbers that belong together in one fraction. Let's use x to represent the side we are looking for (the one with the '?').

xsin(27°)=10sin(65°)
STEP: Solve for the missing side
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now we can solve for x. First we can evaluate everything on the right side.

xsin(27°)=10sin(65°)xsin(27°)=10(0,90630...)xsin(27°)=11,03377...

Next, we multiply both sides of the equation by sin(27°) to cancel the denominator on the left.

x=(11,03377...)⋅sin(27°)x=5,00923...x≈5,01

The final step rounds the answer to two decimal places, as required in the instructions. Based on the diagram, we expected the answer to be shorter than than 10. And it is! Remember to compare your answer to the diagram if the diagram is to scale.

The length of the missing side is 5,01.

Sine rule problems

In the figure below, YˆXZ=a, XˆZY=b, and YZ=d. ZX and YW are perpendicular to WZ.

Determine the distance ZX in terms of a, b, and d.

Answer: ZX=
expression
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by writing an equation about triangle XYZ. You need this equation to include a, b, and d. So focus on the sides and angles which will bring those variables into the equation.

STEP: Add any information you can to the diagram
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We need to find an equation for ZX in terms of the three variables a, b, and d. So we need to write an equation about the diagram which includes all four of those things.

How to do that is not obvious because the diagram is a bit complex. Which triangle should we use? Can we take advantage of the right-angles? It is not easy to know at the beginning. So as a first step, we can examine the diagram and label any extra information we can find in the figure.

In this case, we can know four new pieces of information:

  • ZX and YW must be parallel to each other because they are both perpendicular to WZ.
  • WˆZY=90°−b because it is complementary to angle b.
  • WˆYZ=b because it is an alternate interior angle with b (ZX and YW are parallel).
  • XˆYZ must be 180°−(a+b) because the angles in ΔXYZ add up to 180°.

At this point we do not know if any of that information will be useful. We will find out!

STEP: Write an equation and try to include a, b, and d
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

Now let's write an equation about the diagram. We need an equation which includes the variables a, b, and d (because those must be in the answer). So we need to focus on the sides and angles which will bring those variables into the equation. The equation must also include side ZX.

We can try the sine rule. We can get everything we need into the equation if we focus on the sides and angles in ΔXYZ.

ZXsin(180°−(a+b))=dsina

Now we are in business: the answer must be in terms of a, b. And those are the variables in the equation (in addition to ZX).

STEP: Simplify the equation to get the expected form
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We need to solve the equation for ZX. To do this, multiply both sides of the equation by sin(180°−(a+b)).

ZX=d⋅sin(180°−(a+b))sina

Now we can use a trigonometric identity to simplify this equation. We know that sin(180°−A) is equal to sinA. So the quantity sin(180°−(a+b)) is equal to sin(a+b)!

ZX=d⋅sin(180°−(a+b))sinaZX=d⋅sin(a+b)sina

That gives us a tidy and accurate expression for ZX in terms of the required values.

The length of ZX, as a function of a, b, and d is d⋅sin(a+b)sina.

Finding the side opposite a known angle

The triangle below has two sides given: ¯CB=8 and ¯CA=11. The angle between these two sides is ˆC=54°. These values are labelled in the diagram. The figure is drawn to scale.

Compute the length of the third side of the triangle, ¯AB.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places if necessary.
Answer:

The length of side ¯AB is units.

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

The cosine rule is:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

Start by figuring out where to substitute in the two sides and the angle given in the question.

STEP: Identify the side opposite the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

We can answer this question using the cosine rule. This is because the cosine rule relates all three sides of the triangle and one of the angles.

The cosine rule says:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

where θ is one of the angles in the triangle and c represents the side of the triangle opposite to that angle. When we use the cosine rule, it is always important to identify the side of the triangle which is opposite from the angle you are interested in.

In this question, the only angle given is ˆC=54°. So the side we need to identify is across from the angle labelled as 54°. The picture below shows that this side is across the triangle from (opposite to) the angle.

STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Based on the picture above, we can substitute the values into the formula. Here are the values that we know:

  • The angle θ is 54°.
  • c is the side labelled with the "?". We will use x for this side (you can use any variable you want).
  • a and b are the other sides of the triangle. It does not matter which side we use for a and which for b.

Substituting into the formula, we get:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθx2=(8)2+(11)2−2(8)(11)cos(54°)
STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now we need to solve for the value of x. Start by evaluating all the calculations on the right side. Do not round off during these calcations.

x2=(8)2+(11)2−2(8)(11)cos(54°)x2=64+121−(176)(0,58778...)x2=185−103,45020...x2=81,54979...

Now we must square root both sides of the equation to change x2 to x. When we do this, we must remember to bring in a plus-minus (this is required any time we square root when solving an equation).

x2=81,54979...x=±√81,54979...x=±9,03049...Which means:x=9,03049...or−9,03049...

Finally we have the answer. But there are two different answers for this question: 9,03049... and −9,03049...! Are they both correct? Remember that the answer represents the side of a triangle. And a length cannot be negative. So we must throw out the negative solution.

The last thing to do is round off the answer to two decimal places (as required by the instructions). This gives us: 9,03049...≈x=9,03.

Therefore, the correct answer, rounded to two places, is: x=9,03 units.

Answer:

To fix the equation, your friend should .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

For the cosine rule, the side of the triangle opposite the angle must go into the equation on the opposite side of the angle. Which side of the triangle is opposite from angle C?

STEP: Identify the side opposite from the given angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The cosine rule is an equation about triangles. It includes all three sides and one angle:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

where:

  • θ is an angle in the triangle
  • c is the side of the triangle opposite from θ
  • a and b are the sides adjacent to θ

For the cosine rule, one side is more important that the other two:

The side opposite from the angle in the triangle must be on the opposite side of the equation. And that is why the equation in the question is wrong:

92=6_2+82−2(6_)(8)cosC_

The higlighted side and angle should not be on the same side of the equation, since the side 6 is opposite the angle C.

So 6 must go in the correct spot. But sides 9 and 8 are more flexible. The correct equation for this triangle can be either of these:

62=92+82−2(9)(8)cosCor62=82+92−2(8)(9)cosC

To fix the equation, swap 6 with 9.

Using the cosine rule: is there enough information?

The triangle below has two sides with lengths 5 and 7. The triangle has two known angles, which are 78° and 57°. One of the sides is missing and it is labelled '?'.

Answer the two questions below about this diagram and the cosine rule.

Answer:
  1. Can you find the missing side using the cosine rule?
  2. Why / why not?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Compare the information given about the triangle to the cosine rule. Is there enough information to use the cosine rule?

STEP: Compare the information given to the information used in the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

This question is about the information in the cosine rule. The cosine rule connects all three sides of a triangle and one angle:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

In this equation, a, b, and c are the sides of the triangle and θ is the angle opposite from side c in the triangle.

In total, the cosine rule contains four pieces of information about a triangle: all three sides and one angle. If we know any three of those four values we can use the cosine rule to calculate the fourth value. But if we have fewer than three of those values we do not have enough information to use the cosine rule.

In this case we know the values for a and b in the cosine rule, as well as angle θ=57°. That accounts for three of the four values in the cosine rule: the only thing missing is the third side (which is c in the cosine rule). So we can use the cosine rule to calculate the value of the unknown side.

NOTE: The second angle in the triangle (the 78° angle) is extra information: we do not need it in the cosine rule.
STEP: Select the correct answers
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Based on the reasons above we can select the correct answer choices:

  1. Can you find the missing side using the cosine rule? Yes
  2. Why / why not? We know 3 of the 4 things in the cosine rule.

Finding an angle with the cosine rule

The triangle below has all three sides labelled. ¯ZX=10 units, ¯XY=9 units, and ¯ZY=4 units. The figure is drawn to scale.

Find the measure of the angle ˆZ.

TIP: The question states that the figure is drawn to scale. And the angle that you want is acute. In fact, it must be quite a bit less than 90°. So make sure your answer agrees with that!
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places if necessary.
Answer:

The measure of angle ˆZ is °.

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by writing the cosine rule equation. Then substitute in the lengths for the sides of the triangle.

STEP: Identify the side and angle opposite pair for the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We need to find the size of angle ˆZ in the triangle. We can find this angle using the cosine rule. The cosine rule relates all three sides of the triangle and one of the angles.

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

To use this equation, we must be sure that the side we use for c in the formula is the side of the triangle across from (opposite) angle θ. These opposites are shown below:

So in this case c=9 because that is the side of the triangle opposite from angle ˆZ.

STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

We can organise the information that we need for the cosine rule:

  • We want to find the angle, so we will use x in place of θ (ˆZ would also be a good choice).
  • c is the side across from the angle, so c=9.
  • a and b are the other sides of the triangle. It does not matter which side we use for a and which for b.

Substitute all these values into the equation:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ(9)2=(4)2+(10)2−2(4)(10)cosx
STEP: Solve for the angle
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

Now we need to do all of the calculations required to solve for x.

(9)2=(4)2+(10)2−2(4)(10)cosx81=16+100−(80)cosx81=116−80⋅cosx−35=−80⋅cosx−35−80=cosx716=cosx

At this point we must use the inverse cosine function, cos−1. When we use cos−1, we will get one answer from the calculator. But we must remember that there is a second solution, which is the negative of what we get from the calculator (because cosx=cos(−x)). And in addition to that, we must add +360°k to each solution.

716=cosxcos−1(716)=cos−1(cosx)This produces two solutions:x=64,05552...°+360°k,k∈Zorx=−64,05552...°+360°k,k∈Z
STEP: Determine the final answer
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

To finish the solution we need to use the fact that we are solving for an angle in a triangle. That means two things: (a) the answer cannot be negative because angles in a triangle cannot be negative numbers, and (b) the answer cannot be larger than 180° because the angles in a triangle add up to 180° (they cannot be larger than that).

That means we can ignore the negative angle (in the second solution above). And we can also ignore the 360°k terms. That leaves just the one acceptable answer:

x=64,05552...°

The instructions told us to round to two decimal places. So: 64,05552...°≈64,06°. Remember to compare your answer to the diagram: is 64,06° a reasonable answer for ˆZ?

Therefore the correct answer is ˆZ=64,06°.

Cosine rule connections

  1. The cosine rule is about triangles, including right-angled triangles. And if you use a 90° angle in the cosine rule, it becomes the same as another important equation. Which statement below identifies what happens if we use a 90° angle in the cosine rule?

    Choices If you use a 90° angle is the cosine rule...
    A it becomes the theorem of Pythagoras
    B you get all the special triangle angle choices
    C the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is 180°
    D it changes into the sine rule
    Answer: The correct statement is choice .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a triangle to represent the situation described in the question: a right-angled triangle. Then work out the cosine rule including the right-angle.

    STEP: Connect the cosine rule to the theorem of Pythagoras
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The cosine rule works for any triangle. But suppose that there is a 90° angle in the triangle. Then we have a right-angled triangle.

    Since this is a right-angled triangle, the sides obey the theorem of Pythagoras. But the sides also obey the cosine rule. And if we include the right-angle when we write the cosine rule, it ends up being equivalent to the theorem of Pythagoras. (Question 2 is about why this happens.)

    Using a 90° angle in the cosine rule gives us the theorem of Pythagoras.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. The table below contains a proof. The proof shows that the cosine rule simplifies to the theorem of Pythagoras if the angle in the cosine rule is 90°. However, there is one step and one reason missing. Select the correct option from each list of choices to complete the proof.

    Answer:
    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    c2=a2+b2−2abcosˆC
    c2=a2+b2−2abcos(90°) Substitute ˆC=90°
    Evaluate cos(90°)=0
    c2=a2+b2 Multiply by 0
    Theorem of Pythagoras applies to ΔABC c is the hypotenuse, a and b are legs
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Start by analysing the steps and reasons which are already shown. Think about what they mean. Then try to decide what the missing pieces should be.

    STEP: Select the correct step and reason
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The proof in the question connects the cosine rule to right-angled triangles. If we substitute 90° for θ, the cosine rule becomes the same as the theorem of Pythagoras. In other words, the cosine rule ends up becoming equivalent to the equation c2=a2+b2. This connection is based on the fact that cos90° is equal to 0.

    The table below shows the complete proof. The correct answers are in the shaded blocks.

    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    c2=a2+b2−2abcosˆC Cosine rule using ˆC
    c2=a2+b2−2abcos(90°) Substitute ˆC=90°
    c2=a2+b2−2ab(0) Evaluate cos(90°)=0
    c2=a2+b2 Multiply by 0
    Theorem of Pythagoras applies to ΔABC c is the hypotenuse, a and b are legs

Finding an adjacent side

TIP: The question states that the figure is drawn roughly to scale. Make sure your answer is reasonable compared to the appearance of the figure.

Answer: Side ¯CB is units.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 6 / 6 points left]

Start by writing down an equation for the triangle. Use the cosine rule.

STEP: Identify the side and angle opposite pair for the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 5 / 6 points left]

The cosine rule says: c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ where c is the side of the triangle opposite to angle θ. So the first thing to do is identify the side of the triangle which is opposite from the angle of interest. In this question, the side we need is adjacent to the angle labelled as θ. It can be helpful to make these opposites more obvious, like this:

STEP: Substitute known values into the formula
[−2 points ⇒ 3 / 6 points left]

Now we can write a cosine rule equation. For the two sides which are not opposite to the angle, it does not matter which is a and which is b. Let's put x in place of the '?.'

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ(13)2=(x)2+(8)2−2(x)(8)cosθ

Now substitute in the value of cosθ, which is equal to −16. We are subsituting here for the entire cosine factor, not the angle itself.

(13)2=(x)2+(8)2−2(x)(8)cosθ(13)2=(x)2+(8)2−2(x)(8)(−16)
STEP: Arrange the equation into standard form
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 6 points left]

This is a quadratic equation. We need to arrange it in standard form.

(13)2=(x)2+(8)2−2(x)(8)(−16)169=x2+64+83x0=x2+83x+64−1690=x2+83x−105

We can help ourselves by removing the fraction. To do that, multiply the equation (on both sides) by 3. It is important to see that this does not change the zero on the left side of the equation.

(3)0=(x2+83x−105)(3)0=3x2+8x−315
STEP: Solve the equation with the quadratic formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 6 points left]

Now use the quadratic formula to find the solutions (we can expet two solutions because the equation is quadratic).

x=−b±√b2−4ac2a=−(8)±√(8)2−4(3)(−315)2(3)=−8±√64+37806=−8±√38446=−8±626

Now we can split the two answers apart (separate the plus-minus).

x=−8+626 or x=−8−626=546 or =−706=9 or =−11,66666...

We get two answers. But these values are for the side of a triangle, which is a distance. So we must throw out any negative answers. One of the answers above is negative, so we will drop it! That leaves one acceptable (positive) answer.

The correct answer, rounded to two places, is: x=9.

where θ is one of the angles in the triangle and c represents the side of the triangle opposite to that angle. When we use the cosine rule, it is always important to identify the side of the triangle which is opposite from the angle you are interested in.

In this question, the only angle given is ˆY=89°. So the side we need to identify is across from the angle labelled as 89°. The picture below shows that this side is across the triangle from (opposite to) the angle.

STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Based on the picture above, we can substitute the values into the formula. Here are the values that we know:

  • The angle θ is 89°.
  • c is the side labelled with the "?". We will use x for this side (you can use any variable you want).
  • a and b are the other sides of the triangle. It does not matter which side we use for a and which for b.

Substituting into the formula, we get:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθx2=(4)2+(7)2−2(4)(7)cos(89°)
STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now we need to solve for the value of x. Start by evaluating all the calculations on the right side. Do not round off during these calcations.

x2=(4)2+(7)2−2(4)(7)cos(89°)x2=16+49−(56)(0,01745...)x2=65−0,97733...x2=64,02266...

Now we must square root both sides of the equation to change x2 to x. When we do this, we must remember to bring in a plus-minus (this is required any time we square root when solving an equation).

x2=64,02266...x=±√64,02266...x=±8,00141...Which means:x=8,00141...or−8,00141...

Finally we have the answer. But there are two different answers for this question: 8,00141... and −8,00141...! Are they both correct? Remember that the answer represents the side of a triangle. And a length cannot be negative. So we must throw out the negative solution.

The last thing to do is round off the answer to two decimal places (as required by the instructions). This gives us: 8,00141...≈x=8.

Therefore, the correct answer, rounded to two places, is: x=8 units.

The cosine rule: finding mistakes

The triangle below has sides 4, 5, and 7, and one angle labelled as B. A friend of yours writes down the cosine rule for this triangle, but there is a mistake.

Incorrect equation:

42=52+72−2(5)(7)cosB

How can your friend correct the equation?

Answer:

To fix the equation, your friend should .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

For the cosine rule, the side of the triangle opposite the angle must go into the equation on the opposite side of the angle. Which side of the triangle is opposite from angle B?

STEP: Identify the side opposite from the given angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The cosine rule is an equation about triangles. It includes all three sides and one angle:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

where:

  • θ is an angle in the triangle
  • c is the side of the triangle opposite from θ
  • a and b are the sides adjacent to θ

For the cosine rule, one side is more important that the other two:

The side opposite from the angle in the triangle must be on the opposite side of the equation. And that is why the equation in the question is wrong:

42=5_2+72−2(5_)(7)cosB_

The higlighted side and angle should not be on the same side of the equation, since the side 5 is opposite the angle B.

So 5 must go in the correct spot. But sides 7 and 4 are more flexible. The correct equation for this triangle can be either of these:

52=72+42−2(7)(4)cosBor52=42+72−2(4)(7)cosB

To fix the equation, swap 5 with 4.

Submit your answer as:

Using the cosine rule: is there enough information?

The triangle below has a side with a length of 6. One of the angles is 75° and another angle is 57°. One of the angles is missing and it is labelled '?'.

Answer the two questions below about this diagram and the cosine rule.

Answer:
  1. Can you find the missing angle using the cosine rule?
  2. Why / why not?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Compare the information given about the triangle to the cosine rule. Is there enough information to use the cosine rule?

STEP: Compare the information given to the information used in the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

This question is about the information in the cosine rule. The cosine rule connects all three sides of a triangle and one angle:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

In this equation, a, b, and c are the sides of the triangle and θ is the angle opposite from side c in the triangle.

In total, the cosine rule contains four pieces of information about a triangle: all three sides and one angle. If we know any three of those four values we can use the cosine rule to calculate the fourth value. But if we have fewer than three of those values we do not have enough information to use the cosine rule.

In this case the cosine rule can't do the job: we cannot find the missing angle using the cosine rule unless we know the other two sides of the triangle. In other words, we only know one of the four values in the cosine rule. So it is not possible to calculate the value of the unknown angle with the cosine rule.

NOTE: It is possible to find the third angle because the three angles have a sum of 180°. But we cannot find the value using the cosine rule.
STEP: Select the correct answers
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Based on the reasons above we can select the correct answer choices:

  1. Can you find the missing angle using the cosine rule? No
  2. Why / why not? There is not enough information given.
Submit your answer as: and

Finding an angle with the cosine rule

The triangle below has all three sides labelled. ¯CA=4 units, ¯AB=5 units, and ¯CB=6 units. The figure is drawn to scale.

Determine the measure of the angle ˆB.

TIP: The question states that the figure is drawn to scale. And the angle that you want is acute. In fact, it must be quite a bit less than 90°. So make sure your answer agrees with that!
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places if necessary.
Answer:

The measure of angle ˆB is °.

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by writing the cosine rule equation. Then substitute in the lengths for the sides of the triangle.

STEP: Identify the side and angle opposite pair for the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We need to find the size of angle ˆB in the triangle. We can find this angle using the cosine rule. The cosine rule relates all three sides of the triangle and one of the angles.

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ

To use this equation, we must be sure that the side we use for c in the formula is the side of the triangle across from (opposite) angle θ. These opposites are shown below:

So in this case c=4 because that is the side of the triangle opposite from angle ˆB.

STEP: Substitute into the formula
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

We can organise the information that we need for the cosine rule:

  • We want to find the angle, so we will use x in place of θ (ˆB would also be a good choice).
  • c is the side across from the angle, so c=4.
  • a and b are the other sides of the triangle. It does not matter which side we use for a and which for b.

Substitute all these values into the equation:

c2=a2+b2−2abcosθ(4)2=(5)2+(6)2−2(5)(6)cosx
STEP: Solve for the angle
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

Now we need to do all of the calculations required to solve for x.

(4)2=(5)2+(6)2−2(5)(6)cosx16=25+36−(60)cosx16=61−60⋅cosx−45=−60⋅cosx−45−60=cosx34=cosx

At this point we must use the inverse cosine function, cos−1. When we use cos−1, we will get one answer from the calculator. But we must remember that there is a second solution, which is the negative of what we get from the calculator (because cosx=cos(−x)). And in addition to that, we must add +360°k to each solution.

34=cosxcos−1(34)=cos−1(cosx)This produces two solutions:x=41,40962...°+360°k,k∈Zorx=−41,40962...°+360°k,k∈Z
STEP: Determine the final answer
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

To finish the solution we need to use the fact that we are solving for an angle in a triangle. That means two things: (a) the answer cannot be negative because angles in a triangle cannot be negative numbers, and (b) the answer cannot be larger than 180° because the angles in a triangle add up to 180° (they cannot be larger than that).

That means we can ignore the negative angle (in the second solution above). And we can also ignore the 360°k terms. That leaves just the one acceptable answer:

x=41,40962...°

The instructions told us to round to two decimal places. So: 41,40962...°≈41,41°. Remember to compare your answer to the diagram: is 41,41° a reasonable answer for ˆB?

Therefore the correct answer is ˆB=41,41°.

To finish the solution we need to use the fact that we are solving for an angle in a triangle. That means two things: (a) the answer cannot be negative because angles in a triangle cannot be negative numbers, and (b) the answer cannot be larger than 180° because the angles in a triangle add up to 180° (they cannot be larger than that).

That means we can ignore the negative angle (in the second solution above). And we can also ignore the 360°k terms. That leaves just the one acceptable answer:

The cosine rule: identifying the correct sides and angles

y2=z2+x2−2zx⋅cos(?)

Which of the following choices belongs in the place of the '?' in the formula?

Answer: The missing quantity is: .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

When using the cosine rule, you must remember that the angle used in the cos function must be opposite from the side on the other side of the equal sign in the formula. For example, if one writes h2=j2+k2−2jkcosˆG, then side h must be across the triangle from the angle ˆG.

STEP: Connect the sides and angles in the diagram according to the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The cosine rule has three sides and one angle in it. We must make sure that the sides and angles go in the correct places in the formula! Specifically, the side which is opposite the angle in the triangle must go on the opposite side of the equation from the angle.

In this question, we are looking for one of the angles:

y2=z2+x2−2zx⋅cos(?)

This angle must be the angle across from side y. Looking at the figure, we can see that this must be angle Y.

The correct choice from the list is Y.

When using the cosine rule, you must remember that the angle used in the cos function must be opposite from the side on the other side of the equal sign in the formula. For example, if one writes h2=j2+k2−2jkcosˆG, then side h must be across the triangle from the angle ˆG.

STEP: Connect the sides and angles in the diagram according to the cosine rule
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The cosine rule has three sides and one angle in it. We must make sure that the sides and angles go in the correct places in the formula! Specifically, the side which is opposite the angle in the triangle must go on the opposite side of the equation from the angle.

In this question, we are looking for one of the sides:

(?)2=y2+z2−2yz⋅cosX

In fact, we are trying to find the side which belongs on the left side of the equation! This is always the side of the triangle which is opposite from the angle on the right side of the equation. In this case the equation includes the angle X. Therefore the side which goes in the place of the question mark must be x because it is opposite angle X in the triangle.

The correct choice from the list is x.

Cosine rule connections

  1. The cosine rule is about triangles, including right-angled triangles. And if you use a 90° angle in the cosine rule, it becomes the same as another important equation. Which statement below identifies what happens if we use a 90° angle in the cosine rule?

    Choices If you use a 90° angle is the cosine rule...
    A it becomes the isosceles triangle calculation
    B you get all the special triangle angle choices
    C it becomes the theorem of Pythagoras
    D the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is 180°
    Answer: The correct statement is choice .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a triangle to represent the situation described in the question: a right-angled triangle. Then work out the cosine rule including the right-angle.

    STEP: Connect the cosine rule to the theorem of Pythagoras
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The cosine rule works for any triangle. But suppose that there is a 90° angle in the triangle. Then we have a right-angled triangle.

    Since this is a right-angled triangle, the sides obey the theorem of Pythagoras. But the sides also obey the cosine rule. And if we include the right-angle when we write the cosine rule, it ends up being equivalent to the theorem of Pythagoras. (Question 2 is about why this happens.)

    Using a 90° angle in the cosine rule gives us the theorem of Pythagoras.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. The table below contains a proof. The proof shows that the cosine rule simplifies to the theorem of Pythagoras if the angle in the cosine rule is 90°. However, there is one step and one reason missing. Select the correct option from each list of choices to complete the proof.

    Answer:
    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    c2=a2+b2−2abcosˆC Cosine rule using ˆC
    c2=a2+b2−2abcos(90°) Substitute ˆC=90°
    c2=a2+b2−2ab(0)
    Multiply by 0
    Theorem of Pythagoras applies to ΔABC c is the hypotenuse, a and b are legs
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Start by analysing the steps and reasons which are already shown. Think about what they mean. Then try to decide what the missing pieces should be.

    STEP: Select the correct step and reason
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The proof in the question connects the cosine rule to right-angled triangles. If we substitute 90° for θ, the cosine rule becomes the same as the theorem of Pythagoras. In other words, the cosine rule ends up becoming equivalent to the equation c2=a2+b2. This connection is based on the fact that cos90° is equal to 0.

    The table below shows the complete proof. The correct answers are in the shaded blocks.

    Steps Reasons
    		Given
    c2=a2+b2−2abcosˆC Cosine rule using ˆC
    c2=a2+b2−2abcos(90°) Substitute ˆC=90°
    c2=a2+b2−2ab(0) Evaluate cos(90°)=0
    c2=a2+b2 Multiply by 0
    Theorem of Pythagoras applies to ΔABC c is the hypotenuse, a and b are legs
    Submit your answer as: and
